content: I am not a mechanic in any way but I did rebuild my 1980 Yamaha XS1100 Special last spring. I visit a website for bikes like mine called XS11.com. Guys ask about problems like yours and there's aways someone who knows who provides the answers. With your bike, I'm wondering if every fitting is tight, maybe the brake reservour cap is loose causing a lack of pressure. The guys on that site have mentioned that sometimes they have to bleed their system several times just to get all the air bubble out. Good luck. Wish I could be of more help. Don
reply: I am not a mechanic in any way but I did rebuild my 1980 Yamaha XS1100 Special last spring. I visit a website for bikes like mine called XS11.com. Guys ask about problems like yours and there's aways someone who knows who provides the answers. With your bike, I'm wondering if every fitting is tight, maybe the brake reservour cap is loose causing a lack of pressure. The guys on that site have mentioned that sometimes they have to bleed their system several times just to get all the air bubble out. Good luck. Wish I could be of more help. Don

title: Bikers & bike mechs........Brake problem

content: quote: Originally posted by YankeeeSgt: I am ****ed I had planned on going to the beach tomorrow and eyeball the bikinis. I replaced the front brake paD, I have to remove caliper because of custom fenders. I go to bleed brakes, sister pumping brake an me working the nipple on caliper, worked the whole reservoir an no resistance at brake handle. I did this before, WTF, happined? Did you use C clamps to push the pads in before you put the new pads on? That way it pushes all the fluid back to well so you can adjust all of it.
quote: Originally posted by YankeeeSgt: I am ****ed I had planned on going to the beach tomorrow and eyeball the bikinis. I replaced the front brake paD, I have to remove caliper because of custom fenders. I go to bleed brakes, sister pumping brake an me working the nipple on caliper, worked the whole reservoir an no resistance at brake handle. I did this before, WTF, happined?
reply: Did you use C clamps to push the pads in before you put the new pads on? That way it pushes all the fluid back to well so you can adjust all of it.
